instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Working but partial short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi,

We have that MacBook Pro 13" 2012 which came in as the customer was complaining about a slow Mac.
As usual on these machines, I did blame first the SATA cable but it was fine.
Drive did test fine too...

Opening the case we could clearly see a blown capacitor (<CAPACITOR>C6603</CAPACITOR>)
Voltage drop to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is 0.1V compared to 0.4V on a know good working board.

So sensor issue in the end...

We did remove the blown capacitor and cleanup the PCB which has been damaged since the capacitor was stuck on the ground side.
To me it doesn't seem to be a short in the PCB but I could be wrong.

I also did remove <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C6601</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C6608</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C6607</CAPACITOR> and the power amp <CHIP>U6610</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6620</CHIP> but no cigar.

I did then inject 3V on that line and couldn't find any component overheating.
Same with 5V...

Anyone already had that issued could give some hint?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Working but partial short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So what is the issue now? Is it still slow? Any errors in ASD?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Working but partial short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Well I haven't re-solder the components I did remove yet. I am trying to solve the partial short first.

Are you saying that the partial short is not the cause of the problem?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Working but partial short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have no idea. First run ASD and see if there are sensor errors.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Working but partial short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Well I did put back every part into places and for some reasons the short was gone.
I just can't explain it. However funny thing is I've tried to measure the voltage drop to ground on another board and it was also .1V on this rail...

Anyway, solved!
